result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

1:38 PM Defendant Justin Michael Watts in court along with Attorney Nicholis Schroeder by video from PD office.  Attorney Jon D. Seifert appeared by phone for State of Wisconsin. Position on PH?  Attorney Schroeder WTL for PH to find him an attorney.  Mr. Watts agrees.  Court finds Mr. Watts KVI WTL for PH.

records.descr: Waiver of time limits for preliminary hearing

records.addlTxt:
1:45 PM Defendant Justin Michael Watts appeared by video from the Pepin County Jail without counsel.  Attorney Jon D. Seifert appeared by phone for State of Wisconsin.  Mr. Watts has not contacted an attorney and intends to represent himself and wishes time to speak to Mr. Seifert.  Court advises of right to PH within 10 days.  Mr. Watts WTL for PH.
Adjourned initial appearance scheduled for October 18, 2022 at 01:30 pm.
Memo from Chambers of Circuit Court Judge in response to Mr. Watts' letter.
Letter to Judge Clark from Justin Watts
No contact with any individuals named in the complaint and any Pepin county dispatchers unless there is a true emergency that he needs to call 911.

11:44 AM Defendant Justin Michael Watts appeared by zoom technology by video from the Pepin County Jail.  Attorney Jon D. Seifert appeared by phone for State of Wisconsin. Court advised defendant of charges in criminal complaint/max. penalties and rights. Mr. Watts presently waiting sentencing in 20CF19 where the felony bail jumping arises from.  The harassment and disorderly conduct was mostly with law enforcement and using inappropriate language and making threats.  He has had his first meeting with PSI writer and has a 2nd meeting scheduled for 10/11 and think court should consider cash bond.  Mr. Watts is experiencing mental health issues and drug issues and he could use help.  He is a VA and has indicating he wishes to go to the VA hospital.  If he would be an inpatient treatment in VA facility or under care of VA doctor, State would consider a signature bond.  Ask for $2500 cash bond unless court can craft some other arrangement that would incorporate Mr. Watts getting help with his current troubles.  Mr. Watts, your current residence in Buffalo County?  Correct.  Court suggests Mr. Watts to contact the Buffalo County VA Service Officer and have the services VSO assist him reaching out to the VA for mental health services.  Court orders $1000 cash bond and in lieu of that, if the VA Officer certifies to the DA that you are working with her to obtain services, I would convert the cash bond to signature bond and no contact with any 
individuals named in the complaint and any pepin county dispatchers unless there is a true emergency that he needs to call 911.  VSO would have to contact DA office, if DA satisfed, would modify cash bond to signature bond.
Adjourned initial appearance scheduled for October 4, 2022 at 01:30 pm.
Adjourned initial appearance on October 4, 2022 at 01:30 pm.
